importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, when OpenAI announced new policies for Sora 2 in response to Hollywood's concerns about AI-generated content involving real people and copyrighted characters.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from early 2024 to mid-2025, during which California’s consent law for digital replicas was enacted, and now, the federal 'NO FAKES Act' is being advocated by Hollywood unions and agencies in response to AI platform misuse.

keyTakeAways: OpenAI has released new policies for its AI video tool Sora 2 in response to widespread concerns from Hollywood studios, unions, and talent agencies about unauthorized use of real people’s likenesses and copyrighted material.

AI-generated videos have included fake portrayals of historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr., Robin Williams, and Michael Jackson doing actions they never performed, which critics call exploitative and disrespectful.
Robin Williams’ daughter Zelda criticized the content as 'horrible slop' and 'disgusting, over-processed hotdogs' made from real people’s lives.
Actress Chaley Rose expressed concern that AI could misuse actors’ vulnerability and artistry without consent, stating it is 'kind of cool, it's kind of scary'.
Hollywood talent agencies, including United Talent Agency and Creative Artists Agency, have issued public warnings that unconsented use of performers’ intellectual property constitutes exploitation.
California’s governor Gavin Newsom signed a law in 2024 requiring consent for digital replicas of actors and performers; now, SAG-AFTRA and talent agencies are pushing for a federal 'NO FAKES Act'.
The Motion Picture Association reported that Sora 2 videos have infringed on film and character copyrights, including a fake SpongeBob SquarePants video showing illicit drug cooking.

OpenAI has implemented an 'opt-in' policy allowing individuals to control whether they can be simulated, and has agreed to remove existing AI content featuring controversial depictions, such as fake Martin Luther King Jr. videos.
OpenAI will block the generation of well-known characters on its public feed and will take down non-compliant content in line with new policies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: OpenAI has introduced new policies for its AI video tool Sora 2 in response to intense criticism from Hollywood talent agencies, unions, and performers over unauthorized AI-generated content featuring real people. The AI tool has been used to create fake videos of historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr. and Robin Williams doing things they never did, and even involving copyrighted characters such as SpongeBob SquarePants. These creations have sparked outrage from family members, like Robin Williams’ daughter Zelda, who called the content 'horrible slop'. Talent agencies including United Talent Agency and Creative Artists Agency have condemned the use of performers’ likenesses and intellectual property without consent, labeling it as exploitation. In response, OpenAI has implemented an 'opt-in' policy, allowing individuals to control whether they can be simulated, and has agreed to remove existing non-compliant content, including fake Martin Luther King Jr. videos. The controversy has prompted a push for federal legislation—the 'NO FAKES Act'—to establish legal consent requirements for digital replicas, building on California's existing law. The Motion Picture Association has also reported widespread copyright infringement, underscoring the need for stronger ethical and legal frameworks in AI-generated creative content.
title: Hollywood Pushes OpenAI for Consent
